header.title: Talismans Cabalistiques Magiques & grands secrets des Planettes &c.
header.category: Western Esotericism, Occultism, Grimoire Magic, Kabbalistic Magic, Planetary Magic

central_thesis: This grimoire presents a comprehensive and practical system for the creation and operation of talismans. It integrates Kabbalistic numerology, astrological principles, and the invocation of celestial and elemental intelligences to imbue talismans with specific magical virtues for various purposes, emphasizing the interconnectedness of divine emanations, celestial bodies, and human efficacy in magical practice.

structure_content.chapter_title: TABLETTES & Principes Généraux de la Magie
structure_content.summary: This foundational section introduces the theoretical underpinnings of magic, explaining the nature of celestial intelligences, their influence, and the general principles for creating talismans. It details the preparation of magic squares and numerical tables as the basis for drawing sigils and invoking spirits.

Dedicated chapters present the specific magic squares, derived sigils, and associated angelic and demonic names for each of the seven traditional planets: Saturn, Jupiter, Mars, the Sun, Venus, Mercury, and the Moon. These are accompanied by practical instructions for their use in talismanic creation.

structure_content.chapter_title: Maison de la Lune et Étoiles Fixes
structure_content.summary: This section elaborates on the 28 Lunar Mansions and various Fixed Stars, providing their unique influences, corresponding angelic/demonic entities, and methods for crafting talismans under their specific celestial aspects, often detailing materials and desired outcomes.

structure_content.chapter_title: Des Noms de Dieu & Intelligences Célestes
structure_content.summary: A deep dive into the Kabbalistic framework, explaining the Divine Names (e.g., Elohim, Yah, Adonai), their attributes, and their connection to the Sephiroth and planetary spheres. It discusses the hierarchy and roles of angels and demons as 'Intelligences' and 'Spirits' governing different realms.

structure_content.chapter_title: L'Art de Compter les Noms & Caractères Cabalistiques
structure_content.summary: This core Kabbalistic section meticulously describes the methods of Gematria (numerical equivalence of letters) and Ziruph (letter permutations) for deriving and combining Divine, angelic, and demonic names. It also presents various magical scripts (Celestial, Malachim, Passage du Fleuve) and their use in constructing sigils and characters.

structure_content.chapter_title: Proportion et Harmonie du Corps Humain
structure_content.summary: This chapter explores the microcosm-macrocosm analogy, illustrating the harmonic proportions of the human body and its celestial correspondences. Diagrams akin to the 'Vitruvian Man' are used to show how human form reflects cosmic order, pertinent for talismans involving human health or influence.

structure_content.chapter_title: La Connoissance de l'Astrologie & Temps Opératifs
structure_content.summary: Emphasizing the indispensable role of astrology, this part details how to ascertain optimal timing for magical operations by calculating planetary hours, days, and observing significant celestial events. It explains how planetary influences dictate the efficacy of magical workings.

structure_content.chapter_title: Préparation du Magicien et Pratiques Opératives
structure_content.summary: Outlines the necessary qualifications and preparatory practices for a magician, including purification of the spirit, ethical considerations, and ritual procedures. It covers methods for 'binding' spirits (ligatures) and the process of invoking and operating talismans for wonders and revelations.

key_concepts.definition: Objects, typically engraved or drawn on specific materials, charged with particular celestial energies and spiritual intelligences for a designated magical purpose, often for protection, influence, or desired outcomes.
Numerical grids corresponding to specific planets, from which sigils and numerical values for angelic and demonic names are derived, forming a central component of talismanic design.

A system of Jewish mysticism deeply integrated into the grimoire, specifically its numerological aspects (Gematria, Ziruph) for understanding divine names and their powers, and its concepts of Sephiroth and Divine Emanations.
Hebrew names of God, attributed to specific Sephiroth and planetary spheres, used as powerful invocational keys to access and direct celestial energies in magical operations.
Unique graphical symbols derived from angelic, demonic, or planetary names (often via magic squares or Kabbalistic methods), serving as a direct link to the entity or force represented.

The critical practice of calculating and selecting precise planetary hours, days, and other celestial configurations (e.g., Lunar Mansions, fixed stars) to ensure the maximum efficacy and alignment of magical operations.

Celestial (angelic) and infernal (demonic) entities associated with planets, zodiacal signs, and elements, whose names and sigils are used in invocations and evocations to empower talismans or achieve magical ends.

Kabbalistic methods of letter and number mysticism: Gematria assigns numerical values to Hebrew letters and words, while Ziruph involves the permutation and combination of letters to derive new names and hidden meanings for magical application.

practical_system.description: The practical system revolves around constructing and consecrating talismans. It begins with the rigorous calculation of Divine, angelic, or demonic names using Kabbalistic techniques (Gematria, Ziruph) derived from planetary magic squares and specific magical scripts (e.g., Celestial, Malachim). The selection of the correct astrological timing (planetary hours, days, lunar mansions, fixed star conjunctions) is paramount. Talismans are then drawn or engraved on appropriate materials (metals, parchment) corresponding to the target planet or entity, incorporating sigils and names. The system implies preparatory rites for the magician, including purification and knowledge of celestial influences, to facilitate communication with and invocation of the chosen intelligences.
tools: Astrological tables or ephemeris for calculating planetary positions and hours.
Kabbalistic letter-number tables for Gematria and Ziruph.
Magic squares for each planet and celestial body.
Specific drawing or engraving tools appropriate for the chosen material (e.g., stylus, burin).
Appropriate materials for talismans (metals like lead for Saturn, tin for Jupiter; parchment; specific stones).
Special inks for drawing, potentially made with corresponding planetary ingredients.
Magical scripts and character alphabets (e.g., Celestial, Malachim, Passage du Fleuve).
rituals: Calculation of specific Divine, angelic, or demonic names using Gematria and Ziruph based on planetary magic squares and astrological attributes.
Generation of sigils from these names, often by tracing lines connecting letters on a magic square or through designated magical scripts.
Astrological election: identifying the most potent planetary day, hour, and lunar phase/mansion for the desired operation.
Preparation of the material (metal, parchment, stone) corresponding to the specific planet or celestial body.
Drawing or engraving the talismanic image, sigil, and names onto the prepared material under the appropriate astrological conditions.
Invocation or evocation of the associated spiritual intelligences or demons using their derived names and sigils.
Conjunction of the talisman with the magician's intent through focused will and specific 'ligatures' or bindings (implied ritual actions).

critical_analysis.relevance: This grimoire is a crucial historical artifact for understanding the synthesis of Kabbalistic and astrological magic in early modern Western Esotericism. It provides a highly systematic and detailed framework for talismanic magic, distinguishing itself through its emphasis on numerical and linguistic calculations (Gematria, Ziruph) alongside traditional planetary correspondences. The inclusion of human anatomical proportions as a microcosmic link further roots it in Hermetic philosophy. Its detailed practical instructions make it highly relevant for historical studies of magical practice and comparative analyses with other grimoire traditions, such as the Key of Solomon or Picatrix.
critical_analysis.target_audience: Academic scholars of Western Esotericism, occultists interested in grimoire traditions, practitioners of Kabbalistic and astrological magic, and anyone studying the historical development of magical systems in Europe.
